keyTakeAways: Bear attacks in Japan have increased significantly, with over 100 injuries and seven deaths reported this year, the highest since 2006.

A 32-year-old runner from Auckland, New Zealand, Billy Halloran, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears while running in the Myoko woods, sustaining serious injuries including a bitten-off arm and leg wounds.
The attack led to three surgeries for Halloran, including a hip graft and metal plates in his arm, with ongoing recovery and mental trauma.
Experts attribute the rise in bear incursions to climate change disrupting traditional food sources, causing bears to venture into urban areas.
The Japanese government has announced tougher measures to control bear populations in response to the growing threat.
Local residents use methods like bear bells and loud music as deterrents, and Halloran now plans to carry bear spray for future safety.
Halloran, despite trauma, remains committed to returning to running in nature and appreciates community support during recovery.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Halloran, a New Zealander runner living in Japan, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears while running in the Myoko woods during early October 2025. The attack resulted in severe injuries, including a bitten-off arm and leg wounds, requiring multiple surgeries and long-term recovery. The incident is part of a rising trend of bear attacks in Japan, with over 100 injuries and seven deaths reported this year due to climate change disrupting bear food sources and leading them into urban and rural areas. In response, the Japanese government has announced stricter measures to manage bear populations. The article highlights both the personal trauma of Halloran and the broader environmental and public safety concerns tied to climate change and wildlife migration.
title: Runner wrestles bear in the Japanese woods: ‘In one bite my arm was done’
